Sparks flying and furious
heat give you a sense
of the danger of the process--

technological might as
well as human enterprise

transforming raw materials
into commercial steel products.

US Steel was founded in 1901.

Through the efforts
of JP Morgan,

several steel
companies were merged

to form what was then the
largest company in the world.

It was in the 1930s
that public relations

began to emerge as a
formalized profession.

Photography increasingly
became the medium of choice
for advertising and PR purposes.

US Steel was among the
early wave of corporations

to establish its own
in-house PR department.

The idea behind PR campaigns was
to convey an image of US steel

as a focused, benevolent
enterprise working in the best

interests of its
stockholders, employees,

the public, and the nation
through annual reports,

corporate histories,
souvenir booklets, textbooks,

exhibitions, and
educational kits.

US Steel made a concerted
effort to photograph

the inner workings
of the corporation

and its subsidiaries
across the country.

Images were taken by
well-known artists

such as Russell Aikins, Fritz
Henle, and Robert Yarnall
Richie.

A modernist style and
inventive compositions

captured streamlined
forms of giant factory

spaces, colossal machinery,
and rivers of molten iron.

There are pictures of workers
processing and tailoring steel

through heat, cooling,
rolling, and finishing methods.

What you don't see
in this collection

are images of labor disputes
and the harsh reality

of working conditions
in a steel plant

or the living conditions
employees often
endured in steel mill towns.

A number of PR campaigns were
launched in direct response
to labor issues.

Distinct from the marketing
division, the public relations

department employed
photographs in campaigns

specifically to encourage
public confidence in the steel
industry.

The US Steel photograph
collection at Baker Library

testifies to the corporation's
inventive deployment

of the medium and the emerging
profession of public relations

to shape social views
of the giant enterprise.

It's an interesting case
study, particularly in an age

of the new media landscape where
you have social networks that

are revolutionizing
the reach and influence
of corporate public relations.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
